author: Ryan Hudgins
title: Teddi Mellencamp Shares Stage 4 Tumors Have Shrunk or Disappeared
text:
Teddi Mellencamp is celebrating â€œexciting newsâ€ amid her battle with cancer.
â€œHonestly, the crying is already done, but I just finished with all of my scans and my tumors have significantly shrunk, which doctors believe means that this all will work and that I will be back to myself and feeling good,â€ Mellencamp, 43, said in a Wednesday, April 23, Instagram video.
Mellencamp explained that she has two more sessions of immunotherapy and then will â€œhopefullyâ€ be done and cancer-free.
â€œIâ€™m going to keep a positive outlook because thatâ€™s the way my doctor just spoke to me. Heâ€™s like, â€˜You did this, you got this,â€™â€ she said, before imitating: â€œâ€˜You got that Mellencamp blood, so youâ€™re good.â€™â€
â€œOne update I couldnâ€™t wait to share!â€ Mellencamp captioned her post. â€œAll tumors stage 4 (metastasized melanoma in my brain and lungs) shrunk or disappeared so I have 6ish more weeks of immunotherapy and doctors believe I will be healed if everything stays on course. Thank you to everyone who has sent their love, prayers, and positivity â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸.â€
Mellencampâ€™s pals quickly weighed in on the news in the comments section of her post. â€œBEST DAY EVER So gratefulðŸ˜­â¤ï¸,â€ Kyle Richards wrote, while Tamra Judge added, â€œI canâ€™t stop crying tears of joy â€¦ I love you ðŸ˜˜.â€
The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills alum, who shared in February that â€œmultiple tumorsâ€ had been found on her brain, has been candid about her cancer battle. While revealing exclusively to Us Weekly in March that doctors found four more tumors on her brain, Mellencamp shared that sheâ€™s â€œfighting for my life,â€ adding, â€œBut also for my familyâ€™s life and all the people I love.â€
Mellencamp, who shared that one of her coping mechanisms is sarcasm, noted that she stays positive by planning things to look forward to.
Related: Teddi Mellencamp Has 4 More Brain Tumors: Inside Her Cancer Battle During her three seasons on The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills, we saw Teddi Mellencamp in her fair share of arguments and confrontations. But nothing could prepare her for the monumental battle sheâ€™s facing now. â€œIâ€™m fighting for my life,â€ she tells Us Weekly, â€œBut also for my familyâ€™s life and all the people I [â€¦] â€œA lot of people â€” not doctors, strangers on the internet â€” said [I] shouldnâ€™t be riding, but itâ€™s one of the things I love doing with my daughter. And Iâ€™m really lucky that Edwin [Arroyave] , who I was in the middle of a divorce from, we put everything on hold. [It] wasnâ€™t really the time to be fighting over emails. Heâ€™s been extremely kind and helping with the kids . Thatâ€™s made things a lot easier.â€
Mellencamp, who shares daughter Slate, 12, son Cruz, 10, and daughter Dove, 5, with estranged husband Arroyave, added that sheâ€™s excited to go â€œback to normalâ€ after treatment. (Arroyave is also dad to daughter Isabella, 16, from a previous relationship. He and Mellencamp announced their separation in 2024.)
â€œI want to try new things, travel more with the kids, keep building a life and doing the best that we can, and have fun together,â€ she told Us . â€œThatâ€™s my goal.â€

author: EconoTimes
title: Tesla Cybertruck Conquers Floods as Storms Ravage Southeast U.S. - EconoTimes
text: In a recent display of durability, a Tesla Cybertruck effortlessly navigated through flooded regions of the Southeast U.S. amid relentless storms that caused widespread havoc. This performance highlights Tesla's advanced engineering and marks a significant testament to the vehicle's robustness in extreme weather. Storm Havoc: Tesla Cybertruck Defies Flood Warnings as Southeast Faces Weather Onslaught Massive storms hit the Northeast last week, with several inches of rain, tornadoes, and even an earthquake reported as a storm cell moved across the country, per [Teslarati](https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-braves-substantial-rainfall-and-standing-water-amid-massive-storms/?fbclid=IwAR2uQF5h2Lxlfm2mC_LiostIGqYFl2tk96f0QAAc2Pbmw87u-AgCi5n8e4g_aem_AWRAYb_FRK5a4xpYMvhCdF_AxivwB3KzKw5m_FHiAaakkoVgbgt3dnWedMiv9YKTMd0owvpmSItkIZ9UPy9MC-Sx). The Southeast United States is currently clutching a formidable storm cell, unleashing massive amounts of rainfall in various states. The storm cell has begun its journey out of the country and across the Atlantic Ocean, but not before leaving several inches in major metropolitan areas yesterday, April 10. New Orleans, Louisiana, was among the cities that felt the brunt of the storm. According to [USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/weather/2024/04/10/storm-heavy-rain-possible-tornadoes-southeaster-united-states/73268061007/), more than 118,000 homes and businesses across Texas and Georgia were without power on Wednesday night. At least one person in Mississippi died. The storm also caused significant flooding in many areas, with some regions receiving up to eight inches of rain. New Orleans received five to eight inches of rain throughout the storm, and wind gusts up to 80 mph were also reported. While officials in New Orleans warned people about flooding and advised them to stay off the roads to avoid danger, a Tesla Cybertruck missed the memo. Tesla Cybertruck Excels in Water Trials, Highlighting Advanced Waterproof Capabilities Initially, Tesla had big plans for the Cybertruck. CEO Elon Musk stated that it could cross bodies of water such as rivers, lakes, and seas because the company wanted to equip the pickup with waterproof capabilities in certain conditions. This unique feature sets the Cybertruck apart from other vehicles, as it can continue operating even when other cars would be rendered immobile. Musk wanted the vehicle to travel from Starbase to South Padre Island in Texas, a 6.5-mile distance. As a testament to Tesla's innovative approach, the Cybertruck was equipped with Wade Mode, a feature designed to protect the battery pack by pressurizing it. This unique feature, particularly useful in heavy rain and storm conditions, also increases the vehicle's ride height, allowing it to traverse flooded areas without issue. According to a source, the Cybertruck made its way through some bodies of water while driving along the ocean's shoreline and also completed a somewhat tricky task in a [deep-water](https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-deep-water-test-video/) test. This test involved submerging the vehicle in a controlled environment to assess its ability to withstand extreme water conditions, and the Cybertruck passed with flying colors.

Pour lui, Â« lâ€™objectif dÃ©passe lâ€™accompagnement : il sâ€™agit de crÃ©er les conditions pour valider leur technologie, accÃ©lÃ©rer leur mise sur le marchÃ© et lever les fonds nÃ©cessaires afin de scaler et atteindre des milestones clÃ©s en dÃ©veloppement et en traction Â».
Lâ€™Ã©vÃ©nement a Ã©galement Ã©tÃ© lâ€™occasion de prÃ©senter la premiÃ¨re cohorte Â« NextAfrica Â», composÃ©e de douze startups prometteuses issues des deux continents. Celles-ci se rÃ©partissent en deux verticales : HealthTech, reprÃ©sentÃ©e par les startups Pelican Health, SenseBiotek, VG2D Pharma, Innâ€™Pulse, NeuralTeks, BlocReg Solutions, iAvicenne et Rosetta Omics ; et AgriTech, reprÃ©sentÃ©e par Sand to Green, ISTYA, AgroSfer et IrWise.

author: @wave3news
title: Gas station employees, first responders save man's life after falling off of bridge
text:
Gas station employees, first responders save manâ€™s life after falling off of bridge
LOUISVILLE, Ky. (WAVE) - Employees at an East Louisville gas station helped save a manâ€™s life after he fell 15 to 20 feet off a bridge and into a creek.
The incident happened behind a Speedway located at 11301 Westport Road near Fincastle.
A worker noticed the man had fallen and called 911. Thatâ€™s when employee Aaron Biddix was called over to help.
â€œI just called out can you give me your name? Can you give me anything? No response,â€ Biddix said. â€œHis chest was rising for a second and then he started having a little bit of a death rattle and it slowly stopped rising.â€
Biddix had CPR training after previously working as a lifeguard. He recognized the man was losing his pulse and started right away on chest compressions.
â€œI hopped down there, about a five, six-foot drop,â€ Biddix said. â€œI tried to get him over to another part of the creek with a more stable base so I could do compressions, but by that time he didnâ€™t have a pulse so I figured I might as well just go in and start.â€
When first responders with Anchorage Middletown Fire & EMS arrived at the scene, the man had already regained his pulse.
Samantha Kimbler was one of the paramedics on scene. She described how crews had to call in a rescue company to lift the man out of the creek. The area was heavily wooded, making it hard to pull him to safety.
â€œWe have a special rescue company that specializes in specific types of patient recues,â€ Kimbler said. â€œThey were dispatched to assist us, and they used chainsaws to cut a path.â€
After clearing a space, the company used a special stretcher called a Stokes basket to lift the man.
â€œYou set that spine board down in there, it has multiple handles on it,â€ Kimbler said. â€œIt secures the patient and makes it easier to carry them through wilderness, vegetation, anything like that.â€
Paramedics made sure the man was stable as he was transported to UofL Hospital. Kimbler says these are the kind of challenging rescues their department trains to be prepared for.
â€œIâ€™m really proud of our team,â€ Kimbler said. â€œIâ€™m proud of our department. We work really well together. We train for unknown scenarios and this is why.â€
Biddix said heâ€™s glad to know his quick thinking under pressure couldâ€™ve saved the manâ€™s life.
â€œItâ€™s just not panicking when the situation calls for it,â€ Biddix said. â€œSo thatâ€™s what I did. I think I just helped a person in need.â€
